definitions.definition: to fasten something with a lock; to be fastened with a lock

examples.text: David locked the room and slipped the key into his pocket.
The gates are locked at 6 o'clock.

definitions.definition: to put something in a safe place and lock it

examples.text: She locked her passport and money in the safe.

definitions.definition: to become or make something become fixed in one position and unable to move

examples.text: The brakes locked and the car skidded.
He locked his helmet into position with a click.

definitions.definition: to be involved in a difficult situation, an argument, etc.

examples.text: The two sides are locked into a bitter dispute.
She felt locked in a loveless marriage.

definitions.definition: to be held very tightly by somebody

examples.text: They were locked in a passionate embrace.

definitions.definition: to use a code or password to prevent data on a phone or computer from being changed or looked at by somebody without permission

examples.text: These files are locked to protect confidentiality.
My phone is locked and I've forgotten the password.
Make sure you lock your screen if you leave your desk.

definitions.definition: to get involved in an argument with somebody

examples.text: The company has locked horns with the unions over proposed pay cuts.

wordOrigin: verb Old English loc, of Germanic origin; related to German Loch ‘hole’.
